title: Minimalistic extruder for CTC prusa i3

description.text:
Extruder designed for my CTC prusa i3 pro B kit to replace the stock extruder.

The extruder uses a ball bearing and a spring OR m3 bolt to tension the parts. The bearing is kept in place by any m4 bolt/screw.

Bearing: u604zz u-groove (any bearing with Ø4mm ID and max Ø14 mm OD will work)
spring: Ø10 spring with inside dimension of Ø8 mm (the one i used is 25 mm long)

The part can be printed without support.
This extruder is based on the minimalistic Mk7 replacement from whosawhatsis.

Printer:

CTC prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I chose a wall thickness of 1 mm (two rows) and 20% infill.

comments.text: I thought that since your cold end is more open, it might cool better naturally without any forced air flow. As I understand it, the fan is there to prevent the heat from the hot end spreading upwards making the filament melt there. I have experienced the filament melting above the aluminum block after finishing a print, so I usually let the printer run a little longer after a finished print. Also, the original design seems to be cooling the extruder more than the aluminum block anyway. I have seen solutions where the air flow from the original design also is used to cool the printed filament. That would probably also reduce the air flow making the cooling of the cold end not so efficient. If that still works, why not try just without the fan with an open design like yours?

title: Shelf System - All Inclusive - 25mm - 165mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 7/3/2017: Shelf Bracket Update!

I've created a sturdier, "triangle" shaped bracket, which holds the weight of my digital calipers in-box, without flexing as much. I feel like the previous shelf was just too long to be unsupported. I've shifted the older version of the STL files to the end, and the new ones are at the beginning. Obviously, you will need to print at least 6 of the screws (I recommend 100% infill), and the same platform. Oh, and the only drawback of the new reinforced version is that I needed to print each bracket separately because I couldn't fit both brackets on the bed by nestling the hook of one into the bottom part of the other.

--End of Edits--

*** NOTE: I put "How to Assemble" text in the Post-Printing section below.

This is a slightly adjusted, new-and-improved version of the previous shelf system (25mm width, 140mm length of shelf). This new version is still for a 25mm width desk, but I've extended the arms of the brackets, and extended the length of the shelf to 165mm. This just barely accommodates my caliper box. I'll probably remix it once more to figure out the center of gravity, maybe add a little length to the bottom of the brackets, maybe add another pair of screws, and another set of holes. I'm not an expert, so please, if you have any ideas or suggestions or complaints, feel free to share them in the comments below!

I have a lot of space at the top of my desk's hutch. I used a few headphone hooks for my 25mm top, and they work great, although I wanted a safe place to store my calipers. With space at a premium, I thought to myself "I wonder if I could design a shelf from scratch, that hooks to the desk like the headphone holders, but has a platform?" This is the second iteration of that design.

The previous version worked great, but when I put my caliper box on the platform, I felt like it needed about an inch more shelf length. If the previous platform length (140mm) and width (110mm) are enough for you, great! Go grab that Thing and you should be fine:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2365549

This is the newer version of the shelf, which has the same width (110mm) but a greater platform length of 165mm. I've adjusted the brackets a little (they're taller), and I've given a little wiggle room in the screw holes so you're less likely to break the screws if you screw them in to their maximum depth (recommended).

I'm still thinking about making a new, tweaked/improved version of the brackets and the shelf, so the center of gravity is a marginally shifted, but this may "just work" for me.

I made the desk hook part a little longer, to provide a little more "grip." Hopefully this works well for your application.

As with any desk hooks, if these are a little too big, try using some stickers on the inside of the bracket where it contacts the top and/or bottom of the desk's shelf (like a shim). Some of the headphone hooks I've printed needed a very thin sticker (or no sticker at all), while others needed a more puffy sticker (maybe a millimeter in thickness) to keep it from sliding off.

If there's any interest in different configurations - like wider openings than the 25mm, or different size platforms, just let me know. This version scratched an itch of mine, and I finished this iteration in a few days.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

100% (screws) / 40% (everything else)

Notes:

For this iteration, I decided to print the screws at 100%. This doesn't take significantly more time to print, nor does it take significantly more filament, and the screws are slightly stronger.

I increased the infill for everything else from 30% to 40%, and this makes things a little stronger. I don't feel like the shelf or brackets are going to fall apart, which is nice.

Once again, the platform ended up curling a little at the corners, at 205°C with the 60°C heated bed and Inland black PLA. I'm sure I could have added a raft, or "mickey mouse ears" in the corners, but I figured I'm probably going to be reprinting this again and again at various sizes and configurations anyway, so....

Screws

I designed this with Fusion 360 with the built-in screw library, and created the "Phillips-head" on one end of the screws using geometry. It's just a plus. Works great with my Nest screwdriver I had kicking around. I don't know the official designation of this screw, but I was shocked I got it so close to specs. The screw gets a little brittle near the end with the cross, so maybe print the screws at an even higher infill? Or just be careful screwing them in. They should only screw in halfway, and no further.

In this version of the shelf system, I increased the depth of the screw holes by a millimeter, so things aren't so tight and you have a little more wiggle room before you break the screw.

How to Assemble

First things first - there are pictures. Look through them. They might help answer any questions you may have. If something's not clear, just ask in comments. I'd be more than happy to help.

* Important Note: I placed a 3D printed pyramid on the end of the shelf. This is my pyramid, not yours. Don't complain when you print everything out and you don't have a pyramid. Put something else there! Laughs*

1) You'll need to clean up the parts, just like with any other 3D printed object. If you're printing with rafts or supports (not necessary, but YMMV), you'll have to clean those off first. When I first printed the brackets, I ended up letting Simplify3D create supports, and it made these cute little "squiggly" pieces of plastic inside each of the holes. Easy to get out. The second time I printed, I forgot to enable the supports, and everything worked out fine, I guess. Again, YMMV. Clean everything to a level you feel comfortable with, but especially the areas like the screws and screw holes. They need to be functional.

2) Insert a screw ONLY into the front-most hole on each of the brackets. You won't be able to assemble this correctly (as designed/printed) if you put screws into the back two holes yet. Screw the screws in until they are halfway. If it feels like you're fighting it early on, you may have it cross-threaded. Try again. If it feels like it's fighting you further in, make sure you aren't closer to the halfway mark. Use one of your other remaining screws to gauge. It really won't go in more than halfway. Further than that and you'll probably break the screw. If you do that, print more screws, and try to back out the broken one safely with a screwdriver or a pair of vice grips. If you break it off cleanly/flush against the end, you'll probably need to reprint that part. Sorry.

3) Once you have the single front screw in on each bracket (the front is the "pointy"/"V" part of the bracket - look at the pictures provided) sticking halfway out, you can now screw the platform onto each side. The "top" of the platform has no holes. The "bottom" has four openings. You want to screw one bracket onto the appropriate (left/right) side of the platform. Once it's as snug as it's going to get (don't force anything!), you can screw the other bracket onto the other side of the platform. NOTE: You may have to back the screws out a little, or screw them in more, into the brackets, in order to get things to line up properly. I had to fiddle a little bit to get things flush. It should be fairly close on both sides.

4) Once you have the platform connected to both brackets by one screw on each side, it's now time to gently lift the platform up (don't break anything, don't force anything), so you can screw in the other four screws. The screws should, again, go halfway into each bracket hole. Once they are halfway in, and all installed, you can gently lower the platform down onto the screws, and everything should be flush and level.

5) Install the platform on your shelf/desk, and adjust the bracket by installing shims. I like thin and/or puffy stickers, as they're cute, and secret little hidden things that only I know about. Plenty of craft stores sell them.

6) If you're feeling really adventurous, you could probably glue things together, but honestly, I wouldn't worry about it.

If you're trying to support an object that is slightly longer than the platform, that's fine. But after a certain point, it will most likely slide off the back. I'm thinking of making an even longer platform, possibly with an improved bracket design to support the length. We'll see. Please let me know in comments if you're interested in a custom-ish version.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I used Fusion 360 to develop the original shelf system from scratch, adjusting it by making a copy of the original, and applying parametric adjustments until things looked right again. I also used Simplify3D to slice it up.

Using Fusion 360 and parametric design is awesome, because I can have different versions, and just tweak things in the parameters section, in order to adjust sizes, depths, and distances. If you take the time to learn parametric design, it eventually becomes a lot easier, and it makes it a lot easier to create different versions, and make improvements, later on.

When using parametric design, you quickly learn that it's better to do things the "right way" by setting up parameters, and configuring things in such a way that they either lock in, or more around, depending on what you're doing. When I made the platform longer, the screw holes slid down. Eek! I had to revert that change, and lock in that first screw hole to a very specific point, which would not change when the platform grew in length. After fixing that, it shouldn't matter how long I make the platform: the screws will remain in-place.

Also, tweaking one number sometimes has unforeseen consequences, which are hilarious, but need to be fixed. I fixed them. I'm just learning, only been at it for a few months, but I'm having a lot of fun making stuff from scratch, and then printing them out for use.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=16627

Using the following options:

additional_tooth_depth = 0
m3_nut_hex = 1
pulley_b_dia = 16
pulley_b_ht = 7.5
no_of_nuts = 1
additional_tooth_width = 0
retainer_ht = 1.5
m3_nut_depth = 2.7
nut_angle = 90
motor_shaft = 9
m3_dia = 3.2
idler_ht = 1.5
pulley_t_ht = 12
idler = 0
retainer = 0
m3_nut_flats = 5.7
profile = 9
teeth = 41
nut_shaft_distance = 1.2

Because the huge size of my fixation clambs I made this one to get a way smaller fixation. You'll only need a M4 Screw and Nut. With that screw you can adjust the material deformation, pressing the glass plate on the bed. Fixation can be really strong. There are no more conflicts with the LPA Fanduct now.

The other fixations I found require a glass plates size equal to heatbed size.

Update: Improved the top-side deformation. Also the hexagon nut insertion has improved size.

Issue: PLA works fine with bed temperatures up to 65°C, but printing ABS with bed temperatures of ~95°C or greater the clamp will permanently deform. Printing the clamps with ABS should be better, but didn't tried it yet.

description.text:
EDIT 1 : Placing the belt is a pain in the *ss. If you are a better 3D designer as i am (which should be easy) just take a look and update a better version.

EDIT 2 : use this thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2317181 to let x end stop do his job.

EDIT 3 : Feel free to test with a Cyclops head https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2440523

First, this a definitely not a plug and play package. Yf your are not clever enough to manage printing, compiling arduino, setting up your machine and soldering, DO NOT TRY ! Your warranty would be lost . Do not try to compile Dagoma's Marlin with two extruders if you don't have them plugged on Mks. Don't forget you will have to setup again your Discoeasy with four times more problems to manage :D

If still there, here are the full bunch to get dual extrusion on Dagoma Discoeasy 200.

  1. A slightly modified extruder from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:275593 to use default Dagoma's extruder wheel, i really liked to use a skate bearing :)

  2. Who says dual extrusion means dual filament so need another support : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686007 works perfect.

  3. I wanted to have second extruder on the same rear plate, but didn't used it ... yet at least.

  4. It's quite difficult to manage playing with Mks when it's under the printer ... now it is on printer's top

  5. As well control screen is clipsed on printer's top or stand ont the table.

  6. Of course, the dual head, just a copy and paste on tinkercad from gillywings great work https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2163320

  7. In a perfect world get two identical hotends (used 12 euros e3d v6 Amazn one)

  8. Attached zip is Marlin RC6 dedicated for Discoeasy 200 you will have to update your second extruder x/y offsets. Be prepared to heavily calibrate (meaning compile Marlin each time) : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:124450 , https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1321475 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:832453 helped more than a lot :)

I didn't thought possible but i needed an ATX power supply to heat both hotend, with default power supply Marlin just hung and bugged :(

A. Print everything you need, once printer will be dismantled it will be too late.

B. Assemble dual head and extruder, move Mks and control panel, add ATX.

C. Place filament support where you can

D. Compile Marlin after adjusting your offsets

E. Test cablirate, test calibrate, ...

I used S3d to manage dual printing.

Improvements : many - Of course get a better calibration unless perfect, test, test, test - Add a cleaning head code to gcode - Use a real dual head using same block - Create an ATX support under the table to hide this ugly thing - ...

Have fun & happy moding.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D9yxpbgNSfc

Du coup, j'ai branché les 4 dessus, accessoirement  j'ai mis un micro switch pour éteindre les ventilos non utilisés si j'imprime qu'une seule couleur. description.text:
This funky looking third arm is an idea that I've had in my head for a while. The concept is that for someone who has to often switch between writing and typing. It aids this by keeping the pencil or pen suspended above your hand while typing and thus making it easier to switch back too after the typing is complete by making it reachable without setting the pen down. It sits around the web part of your hand between the thumb and the pointer finger, and as far as the design, it should be ambidextrous in nature.

Additional Parts:
17 gauge steel wire for joints
string for retracting mechanism
pen spring for retracting force

title: Off-Road Overpass - Compatible with Magic Tracks, Mindscope Neo Tracks, Twister Tracks etc.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Welcome to my Off-road Overpass model!

Many brave filament sacrificed themselves to bring you this model. They were slain by lack of experience and much trial-and-error.

Watch it in action here https://youtu.be/wJ7Sy4n2LJU or up above.

This was my very first look at 3d modeling and I owned my Monoprice Mini for about a month prior to attempting to create this. Therefore, I basically learned how to use modeling software on the fly. I have a few months under my belt now and I went back to this model and reworked it a bit to make it perform better and accept more car varieties.

Everything was modeled so it could be printed with the Monoprice Select Mini. I had to set my skirt line count to "0" to get some things to fit on the print bed.

There are connectors that fit into slots underneath each larger piece of the model to keep them close. The design is not perfect, but I am a novice and it gets the job done ;)

Please watch the included video to see the Off-road Overpass in action. This will give you an idea if you want to invest the time and filament and if your vehicles will work with the model.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2625

Infill:

5-10%

Notes:

Using the speed, supports, and infill listed below, it too nearly 50 hours of print time to complete the model

I listed the files in the order I recommend printing. I saved each model in the position I printed it with my Monoprice Mini. I recommend testing the model with your vehicles as you print to make sure the vehicles are going to fit, make the turns, climb the ramp, etc.

I included an optional connector piece that sits between the ramp and the track. I had to use this piece for my Mindscope Neo Tracks car to climb the ramp. The car has a huge rear end that sits extremely low to the ground and scrapes the track as it hits the ramp.

NOTE: 8 connectors, 2 ramps, 2 overhangs, and 2 signs must be printed. Print the 2nd ramp last since you will want to test the other parts first.

SPEED - I printed fairly well at 50 mm/s. Infill speed had to be 30 mm/s since my printer prints it too thin at anything higher. Choose what your printer can handle.

SUPPORTS - Main Body 1, Main Body 3, Ramp to Track Connector. For main body 1 and 3, I set the support angle at something high like 75 degrees so it would only print a small amount of support for the the peak of the overpass. I had some minor spaghetti near the peak, but it did not affect the print and it is never visible. This saves on filament and print time.

INFILL - I chose 5% for the large pieces and it was sufficient enough to get the job done. The low infill made the start of the top layers a little ugly, but my printer always managed to make it look nice when finished.
The optional connector piece should be higher at about 20%.
The connector should be 100%.

SHELLS - 2

TOP/BOTTOM LAYER - 1.05 mm using .2625 layer height

description.text:
This is a small cap to cover the central hole in Toyota Prius wheels from the Gen2 line. The "Touring" model has nice-looking alloy-spoke wheels and you can dispense with the factory hubcaps -- but the axle bolt remains visible. This little cap fits in the center of the wheel and snaps into the same small interior groove that holds the center of the factory cap in place.

You can customize it with your own logo/initials/whatever, of course!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This is a structural part and I did not skimp on the material.

I printed (and deployed) it in Colorfabb XT material, which is a little tougher than many PLAs, with a bit of springy "give" to it. ABS might be a good choice too. Given the environment I would not print it in PLA.

Print this the opposite way that you might think if you're used to avoiding bridges -- it should look like a mushroom on the print bed, with the cap forming a large bridge. That makes the visible part (the rounded cap) come out cleaner.

I prepared this with Slic3r. Supports were ON ("rectilinear" setting with 3mm support spacing).

title: Customizable X-End Upgrade Kit for Prusa i3 / Itopie for trapezoidal lead screws

description.text:
X-Ends upgrade for your Prusa I3 or your ITopie.

I was planning to upgrade my Z axis with trapezoidal lead screws when I discovered that the new Prusa I3 Mk2 was using them too.

I take the x-ends of the new Prusa printer as base and modify it to let you upgrade easily your printer without buying lot of things.

Check attached image for the lead screws settings used on STL files
What's changed.

  • Opposite position of x-ends to comply with original location.
  • Customizable trapezoidal lead screw configuration, check x-end.scad variables.
  • Longer rods holes to let you tune your geometry, even your rods are not at perfect length.
  • Bearing screw holes for M6 size.
  • Reversed trapezoidal lead screws attach, can get to 225mm on Itopie with 200mm trapezoidal lead screws
  • Forgot the rest

Enjoy

For Prusa I3 users, check your coupler size, you may need to change it depending your original z screw size.

Update 19.04.2017 Added missing bearing.scad polyholes.scad files

title: Optical post holder and optical mounting post

description.text:
This is an adjustable optical post holder set. Compatible with metric optical table variant and 1/2 inch post and clamping fork. Set includes four main part: holder, knob, nut, and post. Also available, the composite main part option includes holder base with thread for bracing to table, holder top with post clamp and variable length middle part.

The main holder part has the thread in the bottom for the adapter to bracing in the optical table. The commercial clamping fork could also be used for the mount.

The adapter nut for bracing to the metric optical table has an internal M6 thread.

The post is 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) diameter. Both ends of posts have tapped holes 10mm with a set screw included, M4 on the top and M6 at the bottom.

OpenSCAD file is given for acquaintance propose, work still in progress so no comments inside yet. The screw library (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793) have been used for creating all thread.

The .scad file "Compatable= true" parameters means 1mm pitch on holder clamp thread. The "Compatable= false" 1.5mm pitch on holder clamp thread that is better for printing.

(bullae ex machina) Bubble Botâ€™s name is actually a misnomer. Bubble Bots are not robots, but sophisticated Dry Land Exploration Craft (DLEC) built and piloted by an unidentified race of aquatic organisms. The pilotâ€™s eyes can usually be seen glowing inside the botâ€™s domed cockpit. Bubble Bot is covered in sophisticated sensors tuned to detect mechanical organisms in our unique, waterless atmosphere. When startled the Bubble Botâ€™s pilot releases a stream of distracting bubbles to cover his escape. Created by Todd Blatt (zenix) and Adam Fontenault (adamfont)

This project is... difficult.  If you're adventurous go ahead. It requires about 50 hours of printing, lots of soldering, tinkering with arduino code, moving internal parts, and other electronics work.
Check out BubbleBot_Assembly.pdf for build information.

title: Geeetech i3C dual extruder shroud for 2x 50mm radial fan blower+ 1x 40mm axial fan
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
==== (update 09.01.2018) ====================================
today i was able to finalize my latest BLTouch mount, wich is a perfect add-on to this print:

BLTouch Auto-Level - adjustable, back-mounted ( Geeetech Prusa i3 B+C Dual )
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2751806

=========================================================

3d printing is all about trial and error.
that being said i never found a good Part Cooling Fan for my Geeetech i3C dual extruder. so i took a few well designed models and remixed them together (check out the sources below).

after some testing, i came up with this model.
well, it aint pretty but gets the job done!

BE WARNED:
i modified my printer head. i crafted a thinner aluminium bridge (the silver part your two extruder stepper motors are mounted on). the old bridge had 10mm and my new one got rid of those two feet and is only 5mm thick. that way, my nozzles got below the black plate behind my printer head, so i can use the whole printing plate instead of rushing into the clamps.
that being said, it could be possible, that my model is too low for your untouched printer head. if so, please contact me...

SOURCES (and i'm thankful to...) :

1) 40mm axial fan holder
GEEETech i3C (METAL version): Dual Extruder FAN & LED (V3 with Radial FAN)
by Luca_Benedetto
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2251319

2) Half-Ring Nozzle fan duct
Ring Nozzle fan duct (by SadoMundo)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1964724

3) Blower Connector
Semi-Circular Anet A8 Fan Duct by lokster
www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954001

3) 50mm radial blower holder
50mm Radial (centrifugal) to 40mm Axial Fan Adapter by KDan
www.thingiverse.com/thing:2055378

Printer:

geeetech prusa i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm Layer hight

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

i wanted a strong print so i designed it as a one part print.
on the counter side supports are needed!

important:
turn your part cooling fan on.
i know, this sounds ironic since this print will replace your current one ;-)

the orientation of the print could be a problem, if your layer adhesion is insufficient.
if so, the screw holes might break easily. so be extremely careful and consider sanding/cutting and make the holes wider by drilling them. or else you end up like me (see my right blower: the holes broke and i had to tighten it with a wire)

after the mounting i run a overhang test:
Overhang Angle Test Object by zumili
www.thingiverse.com/thing:1564848

(A) [overhang with direct airflow]
(B) [overhang with indirect airflow]

i expected the (A) part to turn out significantly better.
but the result shows: (A) turned out only a bit better than (B).
--> now the printer can handle up to 65° in both directions very well!!! :-)

(A) left, (B) right - arrows = direction from where the airflow came (B) left, (A) right - the direct airflow improved the quality (only) a bit. (A) top, (B) below - parts broke easily. maybe the layer adhesion is insufficient due too high airflow? X-D

title: NodeMCU and DHT22 case with ventilation holes

description.text: I read that the original closed case made a big difference in terms of temperature, so I added a few ventilation holes to design. Not tested yet, but should probably alleviate some of the issues.

comments.text: FYI, having dealt with this issue with some NodeMCU-based hardware and the DHT22, I found the only real option for keeping readings accurate is to separate the airspaces completely, and vent them both separately. The NodeMCU gets a lot warmer than it seems, and it always knocks the temperature off, from what I've found. In my enclosures, vents alone didn't help enough.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I did realize that myself as well, so I'm working on a complete redesign where the DHT22 is isolated yet still a part of the case itself. I'm not too happy with any of the other models I've found so far, as for one they do not support the type of DHT22 I use (with the extra circuit board) and as you said, they are usually enclosed in the same case. Did you find a good solution to this yourself?
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: So far, what I've done is add a small hole in the side of the NodeMCU case I have in my profile, and reversed the wires on the DHT board so they come out the bottom, and stick the sensor to the side with double-stick tape, with the wires going straight into the box from below. Its not perfect, but the case was designed in OpenSCAD and its a pain in the butt to tweak it. My plan is to redesign it in Fusion 360 one of these days and it'll be easier to add enclosed mounting for it.
comments.author: jumpingmushroom

author: jumpingmushroom

description.text:
A simple Kindle holder for the Kindle Paperwhite. Other kindles will likely fit into it as well, but that's the one I took measurements from when I designed it. The buttons and charging port are still accessible on the bottom of the device, so it should work fine for charging as well. I may change the design in the future to allow the Kindle to tilt outwards away from the wall so it's easier to remove, but it works pretty well for now.

I mounted it with a single 3M command strip, and there are no mounting holes in it for screws, but you could probably drill a hole if you really wanted to mount it with a few screws, but an adhesive should be fine.

title: Pen Plotter Mount with Spring for 3D Printer

description.text:
This is a spring loaded pen mount for 2D plotting with a 3D printer. I included files for both a hexagonal pen (which tend to crack from the set screw) and a standard circular Bic pen (usually made of softer plastic). I have designed it to mount to the gantry plate of my homemade 3D printer. I have included STEP files so that it can be easily modified to suit your needs. Please share as a remix if you do so!

Features

  • Spring loaded so pen pressure depends on z height when plotting
  • Includes set screw located in mount so that pen can be retracted and held up above extruder nozzles. This allows you to switch between 2D and 3D printing without uninstalling the entire pen/mount.
  • Fits standard Bic style pen

Hardware Needed

  • 2 M3 nuts and 2 M3 screws (approx 6-8mm long). 1 set is for the pen clamp and is always secured. 1 set is for the pen mount and is secured when you want to raise the pen out of the way so that you can use your printer for 3D printing without fully removing the pen or pen mount.
  • 1 spring. Mine is 11.2mm OD by 45mm long when uncompressed. Model can be modified to fit a spring of your choice.
  • 1 Bic Cristal style pen (or standard circular Bic pen)
  • Mounting hardware. I used 1 binder clip and 1 M6x6 bolt with an M6 nut. Your printer will likely be different. STEP file is easily modified to remove my mounting tabs and add your own.

For a test print object see my Tree Plot thing here.

For full instructions on how to take a 2D image and turn it into a single layer thick 3D model for pen plotting (or laser engraving or CAM) see my instructable post here.

title: Sram X4 Derailleur bearing upgrade caps

description.text:
The original Sram X4 derailleur gear doesn't have any bearing.
The two caps of the gear are actually used as bearing
Since the contact is between two plastic parts there's a lot of friction and at some point it becomes noisy.
This parts (you need 2 of them) are just replacement caps which allow you to fit a 606 type bearing between the cap and the gear. I would recommend using double-sealed bearing (606ZZ is the exact part model in the catalogs)
That way you are using a ball bearing and it's much smoother.

title: D-bot stepper mounts with zip tie slots

description.text:
The PETG-printed mount plates on the stepper motor mounts for my D-bot would flex a little when the steppers are under belt tension, leading to the stepper being bent over a little bit so their drive shafts weren't perfectly vertical anymore. It wasn't a huge deal, but even a little angle in the stepper drive shaft toward the printer can cause the belt to bunch up on one end of the drive pulley.

I remixed this in Tinkercad by simply adding two slots (left side mount) and one slot (right side mount) to allow a large zip tie or ties to be used to secure the motor hard to the mount, preventing it from leaning over under belt tension. The reason for the different number of slots between the two was entirely practical. The mounts, and where the screw holes are on them, aren't the same between the two sides, so two slots fit on the left side, and only one slot fit on the right. One slot should be enough, though, to allow the zip ties to bear some of the torque from the X/Y drive belts so that the stepper shafts can stay perfectly vertical.

Print this however you would print the stock D-bot stepper mounts. I used PETG, 100% infill, 260 C/70 C, on my D-bot, printed at 50mm/s.

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Plus LCD enclosure

description.text:
This is an alternative for the Wanhao Di3+ LCD enclosure. The standard enclosure puts the LCD in a 90 degrees angle towards the table and that makes it hard to read. This enclosure will put the LCD in 60 degrees angle which improves readability at the cost of a slightly large space on the table.

Note that the new enclosure allows you to insert a micro SD in the LCD to upgrade the LCD firmware if you want to. You will probably need some pliers to do it though.

The enclosure has no bottom. I have designed one, but ended up not using it. It is not really needed.

Note that this is not easy to print and care should be taken upon the support structures. I have included a S3D factory file as well which handles all the support nicely. If you are using another slicer, make sure that the slicer detects 1 mm overhangs. There will be a large, very small support structure in the middle, this needs some modifications, otherwise it could fall during printing as it gets pretty high as well.

Because this is very visible, I would suggest print it at a high resolution. In the pictures I have just 0.15 mm. Yes, I know, it takes a while to print...

For mounting this enclosure follow these steps. There are several guidelines on the internet for the bigger steps. Google is your friend!

  • Switch off the printer
  • Remove the bottom of the printer
  • Remove the front. Take care that you don't damage the fragile flatcable from the mainboard to the display.
  • Remove the LCD enclosure (4 screws). Keep 2 of them, as you need them later.
  • Disconnect the LCD flat cable at the main board
  • Mount the LCD by sliding it into the enclosure. It could be necessary to twitch some of the LCD mounting pins. This depends on the guy/girl at the Wanhao factory if he/she twisted to the right or to the left. See image.
  • Remove two screws from the rod holder on the front. Use one screw to hold the LCD in the correct position.
  • Mount the enclosure on the front panel.
  • Mount the front panel back on the machine.
  • Reconnect the flat cable.
  • Mount the bottom.

Note that these are quite large, not very detailed steps, but you should manage.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Take care on the support structures! The one in the middle can tumble over if not sliced correctly.

Own modifications

Note that I included the Fustion 350 file as well. This will allow you to make modifications if needed.

author: bosbessenbasje

title: Man Ray Chess Set Resized with Board

description.text:
As a lifelong chess enthusiast and chess coach I've longed for a complete, 3D printable chess set. However, most 3D printable chess sets don't have a suitable chessboard available for them. By "suitable" I mean that, if they do include a board with the pieces, the pieces usually do not follow the all important "75% Guideline" for sizing chess pieces to a chessboard. And, if one simply 3D prints their favorite chess pieces along with their favorite chessboard, then most likely the pieces will not look as if they fit the board properly. You may view a detailed write-up about the 75% Guideline here to get a better understanding of the problem: http://www.chessusa.com/chess-pieces-size.html

I really enjoyed simonparish's work on his version of a Man Ray chess set, but it needed a good chessboard to complement it. That's when I found Adafruit's 3D Printed Chess Set, which had - in my opinion - the perfect board for the pieces. Since I liked the size of the Adafruit chessboard, I decided to resize the Man Ray pieces to the Adafruit chessboard following the 75% Guideline as best I could.

Note that I printed the pieces with 100% infill. The reason for this is to add a decent amount of weight to the pieces for optimum playability without having to modify the pieces to allow for the addition of any kind of added weight. Once everything is printed, I suggest you purchase some sticky felt and felt the bottoms of the pieces for an even greater quality playing experience.

If you're a chess enthusiast like myself, and enjoy the art of chess, then I believe you will enjoy this remix of these two great Things. I hope you enjoy it as much as I have!

remixed_from.author: iamjonlawrence
remixed_from.title: Timing Belt X GT2, Printrbot Simple V2

title: PrintrBot Simple X-axis GT2 Belt & Extension Remix

description.text:
I had trouble printing the original PrintrBot Simple X-axis GT2 Belt & Extension (Thing 215294) on my far from perfectly calibrated Simple so I decided to remix it into something that would print without any problem on my standard sized bed before installing the Simple XL Upgrade Kit.  
No design awards for this one, but if it helps anyone it's worth sharing.

VITAMINS: 1 400mm 8mm polished rod 2 10mm M3 screws 8 12mm M3 screws 6 16mm M3 screws 6 30mm M3 screw 1 M3 Nut 1 GT2 belt and pulleys 2 608 (skate board) bearings 1 Printrbot Simple Metal Print Bed For Build Volume Upgrade OPTIONAL VITAMINS: 4 20mm M3 Countersunk head screws. To enable printing over the whole print bed. ADDITIONAL PRINTED PARTS: 1 MotorMountXGT2.stl from Thing 194686 or 215294 2 BearingCap608.stl from Thing 194686 or 215294 TOOLS: M3 HSS twist drill threaded bit Exact Thread. 2,0 mm Allen wrench for the pulley. 2,5 mm Allen wrench for the M3 screws. Rotary Tool or Round Needle File and Medium Toothed File. INSTRUCTIONS: Read through all the instructions one time before starting. All prints were done on my Simple with 0.25 mm layer height on the original build bed. All parts prints with skirt at least 3mm distance from the part being printed The Left Tension Block and Right Top Tension Block were rotated 45° to avoid slicing anomalies. When the parts are printed use the M3 HSS twist drill threaded bit Exact Thread to thread the narrow holes.
If necessary, use the Round Needle File to drill out the rest of holes for the M3 screws. Assemble the left and right base, mount the front and rear arms and the tensions blocks. Don't tighten, leave a a gap of a few millimetres until final assembly. Remove the bed, string and bed carrier and rods leaving the bearings attached to the bottom. Remove the Y axis assembly. Dismantle the base, all screws has to be removed to avoid breaking any part. Test fit MotorMountXGT2 , file/adjust as needed. Place the x axis motor on the workbench with the axis pointing up. Cut the GT2 belt to 450mm length. Wrap the GT2 belt around the GT2 pulley, slide the pulley and belt between the bearings mounted on the MotorMountXGT2. Now position the MotorMountXGT2 with the pulley and belt on the x motor axis. Screw motor to plate, tighten GT2 gear to shaft. Assemble the Simple again. If you are adding the Simple XL Upgrade Kit use pieces of blue tape to hold the M3 nuts in place during assembling. Thread the 400mm polished rods through the linear bearings. Fasten the outer screws to attach the left base on the the two 8mm polished rods leaving approx 10 mm to the left of the base. Screw the Metal Print Bed to the end of the left arms, leave the springs off at this time. Thread the 400mm polished rods through the right base. Screw the Metal Print Bed to the end of the right arms, leave the springs off for now. Fasten the outer screws to attach the right base on the the two 8mm polished rods leaving approx 10 mm to the tight of the base. Fasten the inner screws on both sides to lock the assembly in place. Thread the right end of the GT2 belt through the opening in the right base. Thread the right end of the GT2 belt between the right top and bottom tension block's and fasten the right top tension block. Do it in steps and jiggle the belt for the notches to grab the belt as intended. Stretch the GT2 belt between the left base and the left tension block and fasten the left top tension block the same way. Detach the print bed and mount it with springs attached. Adjust the x axis endstop screw to your liking lock the screw with the m3 nut. Stretch the GT2 belt with the right tension block adjustment screw. Before printing the build size has to be flashed to the firmware, the printer settings has to be updated in Repetier and in the slicer of your choice. I used the GCODE M211 X240 Y95 Z165 to set the new build size with the of the Simple XL Upgrade Kit included. If M211 does not work you have to upgrade the firmware of your Simple. Here is a link to a decent tutorial on upgrading the firmware:
http://help.printrbot.com/Answers/View/3566/having+trouble+with+XL+upgrade The final changes made to these parts were made after assembly and have not been printed / tested. Let me know if there is anything that needs to be updated.

title: M3 V-Slot 2020 Insert T-Nut

description.text:
This is my own version of an M3 T-nut/2020 V-Slot Insert to work with my Kossel Vertices and Robot Digg 2020 profile. The design includes a set of 10 inserts that print together (enough for a bottom vertex or 2 top vertices on a Kossel style delta bot). The parts can be broken or cut apart after the print. Dimensions for my insert are as listed below. I would recommend checking your profile with calipers before you print due to the wide variety of profile shapes that are out there.

Approximate Dimensions:
-Designed to fit an M3 bolt and an M3 nut that is less ~2.5mm deep
-Fits V-Slot that is approximately 3.6mm deep or deeper & 10.4mm wide or wider

I have posted the Sketchup file for you to remix if you wish. If you want to check out the Vertices that these are designed to work with, you can find my 8mm Profile Kossel Vertices at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2360112.

title: MakerGear M2 Dual Fan Shroud (2 Piece)

description.text: This is a fix to increase airflow to cool the plastic on MakerGear M2 Dual prints. This fixes the drooping of layers and lifting of corners that normally occur when there is no cooling fan or a poor fan. I have included both a lowered shroud (to get closer to the plastic) and raised shroud (to clear the build plate clamps if your gcode does not account for them), both capable of cooling both print heads. The shrouds are mounted to the main mounting piece (Fan_Shroud_1) via two M3 screws.

Assembly

Mount piece 1 to piece 2 (of your choice) with two M3 screws. In order to mount to the printer, the hotend cooling fan cover must be removed and replaced with this shroud. Then, the filament cooling fan can be removed and relocated to the shroud. The cover for the filament cooling fan can be used or neglected. I simply did not use it because I did not have long enough screws (20mm will likely work well).

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dDYaUyizseQ

ccStill printing this to test.. the point fits 1.5L bottles with a flattish base.. just tape it on.. I remixed it and made it hollow from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:858319. You might want to add some manual supports around the stepped edge inside. my print had a little stringing but nothing major. The main cone doesn't need supports at all.
The nozzle I remixed from here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13898.. I had serious issues printing the original even after I modded the rear thread to be smooth.. the fins were almost separate .. anyway instead of screwing in a 1/4 NPT compressor quick release which is less likely to be available in a household unless you own a compressor this is made to use the waste schraeder valves tire centers cut out of wheels and throw away. then you can just screw on a bicycle pump.. the valve just push fits into the rear , put some water in first , but not too much.. then push in valve and pump till it flies off .. try varying the amount of water as there will be a 'perfect' level.. too much gives longer thrust but more initial weight which cancel out , too little and it won't go far. i'll upload photos of the whole thing assembled once I finish printing the nozzle section. Forgot to mention I also added a step inside the threaded end to take a rubber washer. should take any std 3/4 plumbing or hose fitting tap washer.. just so it seals better.. the threads aren't really strong enough to handle a load of PTFE tape for sealing..the valve diameter hole goes straight through to the bottle so should be a reasonable jet.. if I get time i'll add a taper there to smooth the flow . but hey it's a toy right ? loll

PS the valve in the photo is complete .. you need to cut of the rounded end.. if you recover scrap ones from tire depots they will already be cut off when they remove them from wheels

last EDIT printed and test flew this... with a compressor attached to pump the pressure in fast , about 6 foot of old galvanized guttering as a launch slide.. and about a cupful of water it flies well over 100'. i'll upload the video soon as I work out how, my kids love it.
https://youtu.be/C0KOMemp9hs

author: jsmvn

title: John's Antenna Coupler RF Line Spacer

description.text:
A problem encountered in the lab
No suitable part exists
A 5 second scribble on a page
A 60 second openscad design
A 2 minute print
A 10 second revision
A 2 minute print
A 40 second cleanup
A perfectly fitting part This is a part to hold an RF transmission line in the centre of a tube as part of a radio experiment apparatus prototype that is being built here. Nothing complicated, just putting it up here in case it is needed in future and to show that not all designs need to be complicated, well planned, versioned etc. to be an essential part of something incredibly complex. In many ways that is the beauty of low cost 3d printing, exactly what you need made as soon as you realise you need it!

• Choose internal diameter, external diameter and height
  • Generate .stl
  • Print it!

print_settings.Notes:: If you use support material for the 1 PART file make sure your 3D printer settings are really dial in so you won't have an hard time removing the suppert material

description.text:
This is a simple but very useful project. I wnated to protect and organize the cable for my microphone in order to keep it in good shape and to avoid breaking of the cable or to not allow the cable to tied it self up with impossible knot to undo ;-)

It can be used for haedphones as well!!

INSTRUCTIONS:
There will be 2 stl files. One which doesn't require any support material (I really reccomend this for a better result) but you have to glue the two parts together and the other one which is all in one piece but it does require support material.

  • 2 PARTS FILE
    Once you have printed it sand really well the two meeting faces then take a 3 mm drill bit and insert the two parts with a small gap between them, then apply CA glue on the two meeting faces and clamp thoose together for 2 minutes. Finally take a 3.5 mm drill bit and with a drill enlarged the hole that should eliminate any miss-allignment and the microphone jack shuold fit in it nice and tight. To finish it just use a bit of sand paper. Look the pictures for a better explenation

  • 1 PART FILE
    Just print it, remove the support material and use the 3.5 mm drill bit and the drill to enlarged the hole for the microphone jack and finally use sand papaer to refine the tear out left by the drill bit.

description.text:
Smaller Intex pools (mine is a metal frame 366x77cm 6,5m3) comes with no angled nozzle and just spray the return water straight for the midle. It's better to get the water to rotate, it will make your skimmer get alot more stuff, prevent algy and probably better in many other ways to!

lowres and highres stl available. thats the only differens of the two files, the resolution.

How to fit it:

unscrew the nozzle from the inside of the pool, press the printed angled nozzle from the backside and in untill enough of it is out to spray the water with an angle!

For what I have heard the best way to circulate the water in a circular pool is to point the nozzle to the side and tilted down abit so you move the water on the bottom of the pool and get all the water to move. Then no alge =)

If it's to tight / to loose, try to scale it 1-2% before print, mine fitted perfectly with standard size.

I'l hope you find good use for this one =)

No bear Fidget Spinner by Murray Clark:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2237509

Add Full color graphics to 3D Printed parts!
In this week’s project, we’re hydro dipping 3d printed parts.

Works on moving parts!
Images can actually wrap around 180° – so you can get some nice details on the sides and edges of your parts. We can even apply graphics to mechanical moving parts like this print in place, no bearing fidget spinner!

Hydro dipping also know as Water Drape Film, Water Transfer or Inkjet Water Slide Decal Transfer, is a post-processing technique that allows you to wrap graphics around objects. So with this method, you can add some pretty cool textures and full color graphics to your projects.

Hydro dipping is commonly used on machined and injection molded parts, but we found it also works great on 3d printed parts. So you’re able to add high quality textures and graphics without lots of post processing. It even works with visible layer lines that you get with 3d printed parts.

description.text:
There are two models... one is the original version and is printable in one piece. The second, for easier editing is the pieces that need to be assembled.

I am trying to make a collapsible cup for camping. I remembered these contraptions from Boy Scouts a long time ago and set out to try to make one. I used Tinkercad, as I am new to 3D design. I printed it out as one piece on a Monoprice Mini, and it worked... mostly. I printed the two outer sections above the base plate with supports. The inner section was embedded into the base.

The problem with the design is that shapes in Tinkercad do not allow for smooth curves... only 64 sided objects. The cup expanded nicely and the sections seated against each other properly. However, there were slow leaks either due to not having smooth curves or the resolution of my printer.

I need someone to help me edit this with smooth curves to see fi it will print into a completely sealed cup.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/177Yni37pFX

title: ATX PSU holder for 2020/2040 alu extrusion

description.text:
Latest Version 2018 This is a complete redesign I did when building my second AM8. The PSU now sits behind the z-extrusions to save some space/width. This version doesn't require any additional hardware/ alu extrusions (unlike the original version). The file named 2040 is for a standard AM8 while the 2020 is for generic use on 2020 alu extrusion. The top bracket can be used with 2020 and 2040, but you can do without it when using the 2040 version.

Old Version
I designed this for my first AM8 conversion and please note that the original version is intended to be used with a non standard AM8 frame with some extra alu profiles. Check this for details: https://www.thingiverse.com/make:344449
I have included a modified bottom right rear corner bracket should you choose to do the same mod to the frame. I recommend using the new version.

ATX PSU
I am using EVGA 500W PSUs and ventilation and holes matches that PSU. There will likely be some differences between ATX PSUs, so check all measurements before printing.

Security
Please note that I have modified my PSU and replaced the wires between the PSU and Mosfet board to 2,5mm2. Don't just use one of the existing wire bundles from PSU as is, The default wire size can't provide sufficient current!

Update 31.01.2018
Published a compact mosfet board mount with on/off switch. It has a separate/optional cover. This cover will work fine with a board with a large/tall heatsink. (i have seen two different versions of this power expansion/Mosfet board with completely different heatsink designs)

comments.text:
Hello,
How can I get rid of the remaining ATX cables?? I saw that you're only connecting the 12V cables directly to the mosfet and there are no extra ATX's cables hanging and hindering. Thanks
comments.author: niftymaker

comments.text: I cut of all cables I didn't need a few centimetres from the PSU PCB. Then grouped the. cables with the same color together and used heat shrink around the cables to isolate them from other cables and components. (Removing all the cables from the PCB by unsoldering them would also be possible but requires a lot of heat). I did add some new cables for the +12v rail and ground. I soldered them directly to the ATX pcb. You have to know what you are doing when modyfing a PSU internally and I wouldn't recommend it unless you are used to doing work like this. Otherwise it would be better to use some external solution
comments.author: niftymaker

comments.text: Thanks for the reply... I'm not planning to unsolder/solder cables, I don't have enough knowledge about electronics to be able to do it properly, but cutting and isolate them with heat shrink seems more possible for me. I'm planning to buy the same EVGA 500W ATX like yours so I will be printing your holder once it arrives. Thank you for the feedback.

I am one of maybe three people on the planet that still uses a Wii, and my favorite controller is my trusty Wavebird. When Nintendo designed the Wavebird controller, its receiver was designed to fit flush with the front of the Gamecube. But when connected to the Wii, it sticks out quite a bit. This has always worried me, because tossing the Wii in my bag (I take it to friends' houses a lot) could break the controller port or part of the receiver when being jostled around in the bag. I wanted to create something that keeps that vulnerable Wavebird receiver from getting knocked around without needing to remove it. And this Thing does just that!

It slips over the back side of the receiver, held on with a friction fit, and creates a flush connection between it and the side of the Wii. Simple as that, really! I designed it to be as stable as possible while still allowing another Wavebird receiver to be put in an adjacent port.

For best results, put a piece of rubber tape along the section that will come in contact with the top of the Wii. This provides a lot of grip, and it also places a bit of tension on the rest of the bracket, both of which help to minimize movement.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Button Bot
oxypode bottonem Button Bots were first sighted after the great arcade factory escape of â€˜86. Their continued survival in the wild has baffled robot experts. With literally only half-a-mind, a Button Bot is dependent on its buttons for sustenance. Button Bots are fed directly through arcade button presses. Once fed, the button brain wakes up for few moments of scrambled output. Created by Todd Blatt (zenix) and Adam Fontenault (adamfont)

This project requires an extensive amount of work and is meant for an experienced maker.  It requires about 50 hours of printing, lots of soldering, copying code to an arduino, gearbox assembly, and other electronics work.
Check out ButtonBot_Assembly.pdf for instructions.
-Todd Blatt (zenix) & Adam Fontenault (adamfont)

title: Two-Piece Locking Puzzle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A puzzling puzzle ;-)
The idea, is, of course, to separate the puzzle parts.
Even if you know what's inside, it might be a slight challenge ;0)

Printing and assembly

Prepare:

You will need:
4 metal (I used steel) balls about 9mm in diameter (slightly smaller shall work too)
4 pieces of metal rod ∅4mm (I used brass rod), each about 28-30mm long.

Sand rod ends so that they are rounded. Best done by chucking the rods in a lathe, but an electric drill will do nicely too.

Printing

Stop printing at 19mm layer height and put the balls and rods in (the balls in the round open holes, the rods in the slot joining ball holes, two in each puzzle half). Resume print.

Attention

If you print through, it will be impossible to assemble the puzzle!

If you can't stop the print mid-way, split the puzzle at about 18mm layer height and glue the assembly together after printing.

remixed_from.author: piratetv
remixed_from.title: tevo tarantula dual hotend fang fan with bl touch

title: Dual Extruder Radal Fang Duct with BLTouch

description.text:
This is my first remix. I was unhappy with the positioning of the BLTouch sensor mount on the (otherwise excellent) LPA Modular X carriage at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2034743. Because it is on the rear of the carriage, about 50 MM from the hotends, I lost about 50 MM of Y-axis travel. Since I have the large bed, it was physically impossible to arrange the stock rails to regain this amount of travel.

This will also, of course, fit any other X-carriage that you choose to use, as it attaches to the top mounting screws of the hotend.

This fits the Stock Tarantula dual hotend. (E3d Chimera clone). If you are looking for a daughter plate for the LPA Modular X carriage for this hotend, the Chimera plate from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829292 works perfectly.

It also has a mount for a radial blower such as the following:

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I got better airflow with less vibration from the radial fan than I did from a 40mm fan on the Fang Duct.

Works for me with .3mm probe offset (G-code G30 Z0.3 after leveling process with my BLTouch)

This changed when I changed from Smoothie stable to the latest Smoothie Edge, so YMMV

Supports are only needed for the bottom area, up to the base of the fan mount. the rest can be printed without supports if you have a part fan installed. Without a part fan, supports are also needed for the top. Make sure you add supports "from bed only" to prevent support material from being generated inside of the duct and impeding airflow.

I had better luck printing with a raft, but you may be able to print this thing without it.

remixed_from.title: Yet Another Wanhao Duplicator Spool Holder

title: Low friction Wanhao I3 spool holder

description.text: I wanted a low friction spool holder to hang rolls or loose filament on. I decided to carve up https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1889438 and use the parts to create what I wanted. This uses 123mm of the leftover 5/16 or 8mm threaded rod from the Z-Brace mod and some leftover 608 bearings from spinners. I used a vice to press in the bearings but you can carefully use a hammer if that's all you have. It's a tight fit so be careful and sand if necessary. I also created a roller to use with just plain threaded rod in case you don't have any 608 bearings. I don't have any rolls larger than 1kg so that's all I can test it with and it's fine. If you find it is too low friction and excess filament is unwinding, you can tighten the end nut slightly to create a tiny bit of drag if necessary.

title: Chopsticks Shelf "Unforeseen Consequences"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 6/19/2017: I changed the cover photo to the super awesome arrangement I made, because no one really cares if you can actually dry pasta with this Thing. They just want eye candy. So here's the eye candy!

Edit 6/16/2017: Uploaded a new cover photo to prove that you can, indeed, use this as a food-safe pasta dryer, especially if you use clean chopsticks!

To quote Cave Johnson from Portal 2:

“When life gives you lemons, don’t make lemonade. Make life take the lemons back! Get mad! I don’t want your damn lemons, what the hell am I supposed to do with these? Demand to see life’s manager! Make life rue the day it thought it could give Cave Johnson lemons! Do you know who I am? I’m the man who’s gonna burn your house down! With the lemons! I’m gonna get my engineers to invent a combustible lemon that burns your house down!”

I made a mistake. In Fusion 360, for some damned reason, threads aren't "modeled" by default. So you put them there, they're looking all pretty, but when you export the STL, there are no threads. It's like, Schrödinger's cat. The cat is alive, the cat is dead. You just can't tell until you get it into the slicer, and by then, it's just too late. No one really checks those things, do they? :)

So I printed it, and instead of screw holes, I just had holes. Or rather, lemons. Lemon holes. But instead of throwing the brackets into the non-recycling bin of sadness, failure and depression, I realized I'd been acquiring a stash of high-quality chopsticks from my local (and utterly fantastic) Korean restaurant chain BIBIBOP (think: Chipotle but with Korean food).

Do you ever go to an Asian restaurant and you feel like, maybe, this is going to be the time you're going to use chopsticks? So you grab a set, or two, or four (depending on how many people are eating), but you also hedge your bets, because you don't want to upset your friends and family who are expecting forks, spoons and knives? So you get both. And although there's inevitably one person - that one guy (or gal) - who uses chopsticks, they eventually switch over to forks and spoons because you can't really get the good stuff on the bottom of the plate/container with chopsticks without looking silly. What ends up happening is one of two things: you're a bastard who doesn't care about the environment, so you just throw that pile of 10 chopsticks into the garbage every time, and they go straight to the landfill, where some landfill woodchuck will use it as a toothpick. Or perhaps you're slightly more concious about the environment, so you ask yourself "is wood recyclable? What about the paper wrapping?" And the answer is "how the heck do I know!?" So you Google it, and find out that the answers differ based on where you live - which continent, state, city and municipality, plus which recycling company you use, or are forced to use, and the cycle of the moon.

More confused than ever, you decide to Google chopsticks, and you find, lo and behold, that there's this chopstick-hoarder on Thingiverse that accidentally designed, of all things, a shelf (perhaps for drying pasta?) that uses 3D printed brackets that you then hammer three chopsticks into, and you're good to go. Wow!

So yeah, I made a strange pasta drying shelf out of a mistake, and now I'm publishing this mistake in the hopes that you, too, can profit from my error and Fusion 360's weird non-modeling defaults.

If you like this shelf, you'll love the real shelves over here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2368917
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2365549

These actually have screws, screw holes that are properly modeled, and a platform, which will hold things way better than triple-chopsticks.

If you absolutely love this idea, but your chopsticks suck (i.e. are different from my awesome chopsticks from BIBIBOP), please let me know what shape they are (square, circular, triangular, pentagram) and what their dimensions are, and I'll totally make a special version just for you (you beautiful, unique snowflake) and post it here for all to see!

My guess is, there are probably two or three different types of chopsticks that are more commonly found in restaurants, so I'm happy to oblige, to help the greater good.

Lastly, please feel free to leave me comments, because I do read, reply, and try to tweak my designs so they're more awesome. I'm a beginner, but I enjoy learning new things!

"Those of you who volunteered to be injected with praying mantis DNA, I've got some good news and some bad news." Ahh, Cave....

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Medium

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Leveling is so important for these things. The bottom's are fragile in the first layer or two, so make sure things are looking good. Watch the print for the first ten layers. I've had most of my failures in the first layer or two for these brackets.

How to Assemble

Super easy:

1) If you have the same chopsticks I have, great! If not, this may work, or may not. Experiment! But yeah, cut off both ends until it's basically an oval dowel. Make sure all three chopsticks are equal length.

2) Bang the chopsticks into one of the brackets.

3) Bang the other side of the chopsticks into the other bracket.

4) Dry some pasta, or hold some stuff! If it's smaller than the distance between the chopsticks, it'll fall through, and I will laugh at you.

I would recommend using some sort of surface to work on, a hammer or mallet to bang things with (although I ended up using the end of my vice grips and my screw driver because I was lazy), and maybe a surface between the bracket surface and the hammer, to avoid dings, unless you like dings, but that's just distressing.

Fusion 360 and Simplify3D

I was trying to develop the all-inclusive shelf, but Fusion 360 decided modeling threads isn't the default, for some reason, so I ended up with holes. Just holes.

Holes which fit my chopsticks perfectly. Win!

Song that I was listening to while I was writing this entire Thing: How It Was Done from Sherlock, by David Arnold and Michael Price.

https://open.spotify.com/track/5Rb6UfzLIezOnXTqoNtLeR

Give it a listen, or just go watch the whole show...it's okay, I'll wait.

title: Hot Shoe Mount with 5/8" stud and lock down nut

description.text: This is a modification of my original hot shoe adapter for lightweight lighting that requires a 5/8" mounting stud. This version now includes threads and a lockdown nut to securely fasten the mount to the camera.  Since this item is load bearing and lights attach with a set screw, it is probably best to print as a solid ABS object.

To modify this design, it will require Thread_Library.scad located at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 and shapes.scad. Print with 100% infill for added strength and to prevent set screws from punching through the wall of the 5/8" pole. Please note that the tolerances on the threads are pretty tight and may require some experimenting to get a lockdown that works properly.

Simple bracket adaptor to fix a Runcam HD 2 to a brushless camera gimbal using the oiginal cradle.
The screw holes are excentric on both parts, so you are able to give the cradle an offset towards the rear or front end or to let them neutralize each other. This way it is hopefully possible to get it in balance even with different weights, for example with or without camera battery.

You'll need two short (thread length ~5-6mm) M2,5 bolts w/ countersunk heads to bolt the parts together.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
V1
This is a 4x6 picture frame that I designed for my girlfriend. I printed each part one at time to make sure that each part would fit into one another. At the moment the push parts work with a little bit of post processing (I used a box cutter to cut a little sliver off to make them fit snug). I had originally planned on a slit at the top for the pictures to slide in, but in this revision that is omitted. To save on filament and time I used cardboard instead of printing the backplate so print at your own risk (should fit in snug, but again might need a little sanding on one side). The heart stands, decorative heart, and flower are all separate parts that can be glued on in any arrangement and scaled to however you want them before printing (I scaled the flower down 75% x/y, decorative heart scaled 200% x/y/z, and stands stayed same in cura). I included an example scene that I like a lot with the colors I plan on adding to my frame (minus the wood texture).
V2
I will most likely add in...

  1. Working slit for inserting photo
  2. Slit at bottom of frame to insert the backplate into
  3. A very slight ledge on sides of the frame to hold picture inside
    V...
    Would really like to make a scad file that will allow choosing size of frame and other customizations.
    Please feel free to comment and ask questions :)

title: Eachine AIO TX03 case for Aurora100

description.text:
This little customizable angled case perfectly fits the Eachine TX03 AIO camera. You may have to slightly change some parameters in the OpenSCAD file to match your printer tolerances. The cut on the back-right-side is for the video-in and video-out cables for use with an OSD, it can also be disabled in the OpenSCAD file.

For use with other quadcopter frames, the bottom 'slots' can be removed. That way, you can also print without supports.

Enclosure for the Smart Citizen Kit V1.1
  • Laser Cut the cover designed for a transparent Acrylic material.
  • 3d Print the case designed for FDM technology.
  • Install your kit + battery inside the case and cover it with the acrylic piece (be sure to align the usb slot with the bottom opening and to align the sensors with the holes in the acrylic cover).
  • Fix your kit to the wall vertically (visor on the top, looking outside).
  • Enjoy your datas on http://smartcitizen.me
    Warning: seems rain proof but haven't yet been fully tested in outdoor condition.

• 3d print the case from the stl file
  • laser cut the case top rastering the sensor location
  • fit the Smart Citizen kit inside the case and align the laser cutter top
  • test sensor values
  • you can add a micro perforated cover for the sensor holes in order to protect from rain and water

title: STEIN Bracelet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you love pentagonal tessellations so much then why aren't you wearing them right now?

The attached STL file is for a FLAT version of the bracelet that can be 3D printed in PLA and then thermofomed into shape with boiling water. With this technique, no supports are needed so the bracelet prints perfectly, and you can make it fit your wrist exactly!

The pattern around this bracelet was derived from a Type 14 Stein tessellation of the plane by irregular pentagons. Designed flat using our OpenSCAD Pentomizer code, then curled around an elliptical cylinder with our Grasshopper wrapping code to make a bracelet shape.

You can also order pre-curved versions of this bracelet at Shapeways in Polished Silver (first photo), HP Fusion Nylon (last photo), and many other materials.

I needed some more room on my road bike handlebars to mount phone and other stuff.

You can buy something like that but usually shorter. This one is 300mm long (210 between handlebars and aluminium pipe) so it is not interfering in holding the handlebars.

Designed for 25,4mm handlebars.

You need 25mm aluminium pipe/profile (painted matt-black) to be cut to desired length. Caps for the pipe are included in the stl.

printed in cheap black PLA with 6 outer layers for strength. I'm using it now for a month-ish without fail.
